entry.title: Automating multiserver workflows with Ansible
entry.content: This talk will discuss using Ansible as a multiserver workflow automation system. I'll explain why I chose Ansible for this purpose and compare its strengths and weaknesses with some of the alternatives. We'll walk through several Ansible playbooks to show how complex build- test-deploy workflows can be iteratively constructed from much simpler parts.

entry.title: Notes for 'Performance of Parsing Short Strings' posted.

div.p: G. Wade Johnson presents the results of some benchmarking of different approaches to parsing short text strings.
Julian Brown explores the usage of the Arangodb NoSQL database as used a website he's working on.

entry.title: Notes for 'Julian in the land of NoSQL' posted.

div.p: Mark Allen decided to cut back on his Twitter use. Since he now needed a new smartphone activity, he turned to DuoLingo and began studying Russian. This lead to the construction of a Perl module to handle declining Russian pronouns, adjectives, and nouns.

entry.title: Notes for 'Using Perl to Learn a Foreign Language' posted.
Notes for 'Floccus, an adventure in Ecmascript 8' posted.

div.p: Julian Brown described attempting to add a feature to a tool for synchronizing bookmarks. In the process, he learned about ECMAScript 8. This presentation explores what he learned.
J. D. Lightsey gave a quick overview of the concept of Threat Modeling and demonstrated approaches for doing threat modeling.

entry.title: Notes for 'Threat Modeling' posted.
Notes for 'Comparison of Rails and Dancer2' posted.

div.p: G. Wade Johnson demonstrates a simple web application built in both Ruby on Rails and Dancer2 on Perl.

entry.title: Notes for 'AWStats Flaws and Making a Cute Robot with Perl' posted.

div.p: This month was a pair of presentations. Mark Gardner described building a robot project for a GEMS conference. JD Lightsey followed up with a dive into security flaws in the AWStats program.

entry.content:
This month, we will be trying a couple of things different with our monthly meeting. First, we are going to be meeting on a different day:

Monday, January 28 at cPanel (2550 North Loop West, Suite 4006, Houston, Texas 77092).

We'll also be holding the meeting at a different time. The meeting will start an hour earlier, at 6pm. So meet in the lobby between 5:30 and 6.

This month, Nicolas Rochelemagne will present some of what he has learned over the past year.

I look forward to seeing you all there, in three weeks.
entry.title: "Looking back to 2018, what I learnt from XS and Dist::Zilla" with Nicolas Rochelemagne

entry.content: Todd Rinaldo will present a CPAN module that he and Nicolas Rochelemagne have been working on.
entry.title: Testing the untestable with Test::MockFile

entry.content: This month, Robert Stone will preview his presentation comparing Monolithic versus Microservice-based architectures. It focuses on the challenges and disadvantages of monoliths and how Microservices address these limitations.
entry.title: Monolithic vs Microservice, Can Davids Really Take Down Goliath?
Performance of Parsing Short Strings
entry.content:
The September Houston.pm technical meeting will be held at cPanel, on Thursday, September 13. As usual, we will meet in the lobby between 6:30 and 7pm, and go up to the meeting at 7pm.

G. Wade Johnson is working on a tool for querying or editing gcode files. He will present an exploration of the performance of simple short-string recognition/parsing techniques.

Afterward, Todd Rinaldo will do a short presentation of new features for Perl 5.28.
This month, Julian Brown will be exploring the usage of the Arangodb NoSQL database as used a website he's working on.
entry.title: Julian in the land of NoSQL

entry.content:
Mark Allen began learning Russian about six months ago. In this talk, he explains how he used Perl to create tools to help him and other people learn grammatically correct Russian.

As usual, we will meet in the lobby at cPanel, 2550 North Loop West, between 6:30 and 7pm on Thursday, July 12. We'll go up to the meeting room at 7.
entry.title: Using Perl to Learn a Foreign Language
Floccus, an adventure in Ecmascript 8
entry.content: Julian Brown has been looking at Floccus, an open source browser bookmark syncing extension. He will be covering some of what he has learned about changes to Javascript.

At the May 10 Houston.pm meeting, JD Lightsey will do a presentation explaining threat modeling. He will continue with a game that helps the audience exercise their new threat modeling knowledge. We will meet at cPanel at 7pm.
entry.title: Threat Modeling

div.p: G. Wade Johnson presented his impressions about being a professional Ruby programmer for the last 2.5 years, contrasted with his experience as a Perl programmer.

entry.title: Notes for 'Ruby for Perl Programmers' posted.
Notes for 'A Look at Bedrock, a Distributed SQLite DB' posted.

div.p: Julian Brown presented the results of his look into the Bedrock project. This project builds a distributed database on top of SQLite.
Todd leads a session to hack on Perl code from the RT queue. The idea is to find and fix at least one bug as a team.

entry.title: Notes for 'Perl Source Hack' posted.

entry.content: In this month's presentation, G. Wade Johnson will cover his experiment creating the same basic web application in Ruby on Rails and Dancer2 on Perl. Since he has not created many applications on either platform, this is close to a first timer experience for each.
entry.title: Comparison of Rails and Dancer2

entry.content: This month, we have two shorter topics that we will cover. JD Lightsey will cover another security topic with AWStats Flaws. Mark Gardner will delve into robotics using Perl and a Raspberry Pi.
entry.title: AWStats Flaws and Making a Cure Robot with Perl and Raspberry Pi
